column1: As he was grumbling at his lot
column2: he kept wondering why it was that folks who had so much money were never satisfied but were always wanting more."Here
column3: said he, is the master of this house—I know him well. He was always a good business man
column4: and he made himself wondrously rich a long time ago. Had he been wise he would have stopped then. He would have turned over his business to some one else
column5: and then he could have spent the rest of his life in ease. But what did he do instead? He built ships and sent them to sea to trade with foreign lands. He thought he would get mountains of gold."But there were great storms on the water; his ships were wrecked
column6: and his riches were swallowed up by the waves. Now all his hopes lie at the bottom of the sea
column7: and his great wealth has vanished."There are many such cases. Men seem to be never satisfied unless they gain the whole world."As for me
column8: if I had only enough to eat and to wear
column9: I would not want anything more."Just at that moment Fortune came down the street.
